newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft sees $300 million WebTV charge.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft sees $300 million WebTV charge.

text.p: Microsoft Corp Chief Financial Officer Mike Brown said Thursday the software giant will take a one-time charge of about $300 million when it closes its planned acquisition of WebTV Networks Inc.
In a conference call with analysts and reporters, Brown said the non-deductible charge would reduce earnings in the affected quarter by about $0.20 per share.
He also said the proposed acquisition would dilute quarterly earnings by about $0.01 per share for about a year after the deal closes.

Microsoft announced earlier this month it had agreed to pay $425 million in cash and stock to buy the privately held maker of systems that allow consumers to use their televisions to access the Internet.
At the time Microsoft said it would write off up to 60 percent of the purchase price either in the current fiscal fourth quarter or in the first quarter of fiscal 1998.
Also in the conference call, company treasurer Greg Maffei said Microsoft's Internet Explorer browser had a 30 percent market share in the latest quarter, up from 12 percent in the prior quarter.
Microsoft gives away the product, which competes with market-leading Navigator browser from Netscape Communications Corp.
